title: What is a reasonable retainer fee to pay a lawyer to negotiate a settlement with a debtor's lawyer concerning a
question: non-dischargeable debt on a chapter 7 bankruptcy?
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy court,341 meeting of creditors,Bankruptcy adversary proceeding,Bankruptcy documents,Debt,Nondischargeable debts,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Working with a lawyer,Fees,Federal court
answers: My question is why the attorney would the attorney be willing to do this for such a small retainer? It is very unlikely the project can be completed or substantial progress made with such a small retainer.

Without know what amount of time is being estimated by the lawyer you are talking to, I think the amount is reasonable. Personally, I would not file an Adversary Proceeding Complaint or an Answer to a complaint for a retainer that low. Much more time is involved in an Adversary than it might appear at first if the job is going to be done adequately. The attorney's fees in an Adversary, depending on complexity of facts, number of witnesses and investigation time needed, plus court proceedings, can easily exceed $15,000.
Depending on the facts of the underlying dispute as to dischargeability of the debt, I think you are getting off cheap.

I concur with my colleagues and add: If at this point in your relationship with your lawyer you are getting opinions from other lawyers about the arrangement, it appears something is missing here. If you are uncomfortable with the proposal, say that and say what you are comfortable with. Everything is negotiable. If your lawyer has presented his/her best offer and is unwilling to consider any counter offers, you can take it or leave it. Non-dischargeability complaints are difficult to win in most cases. Perhaps some kind of a contingency deal might get the attorney fully on board with winning the case.
Sounds eminently reasonable and fair (without having read the entire retainer).
That is very reasonable. Of course, everything depends on the facts of the case and whether or not the debt is non-dischargeable.
That appears to be very reasonable.
